title: Trump’s Affinity for Putin Will Be Tested at High-Risk Summit in Alaska
summary: President Trump has largely held back from harsh criticism of Vladimir V. Putin personally, despite recent complaints about Russian intransigence in ending the war in Ukraine.

title: Zelensky and Other European Leaders Work With Trump on Russia-Ukraine Strategy
summary: Chancellor Friedrich Merz and several allies played host to President Trump for a video call, the latest in a summer-long effort to hold ranks in supporting Ukraine.

title: Trump and Putin Could Decide Others’ Fates, Echoing Yalta Summit
summary: In 1945, the map of Europe was redrawn in Yalta without input from the affected countries. Ukraine and Europe fear a repeat in Alaska.

title: Why Surrendering a Key Eastern Region Would Be Hard for Ukraine
summary: As President Trump talks of land swaps, Ukrainians find it difficult to imagine giving up the Donbas, for military, humanitarian and political reasons.

title: JD Vance Meets Nigel Farage, Another Right Wing Populist, on Trip to UK
summary: JD Vance, the vice president, sat down with Nigel Farage, a longtime supporter of President Trump whose party, Reform U.K., is leading in British polls.

title: Trump Warns of Economic Disaster if Court Strikes Down Tariffs
summary: The president has crowed about the billions of dollars collected so far from tariffs. That money could be at risk if the White House loses the legal battle.

title: National Guard Deploys in D.C. as Trump’s Crime Crackdown Starts to Take Shape
summary: Troops appeared near the Washington Monument on Tuesday evening. But it remained unclear whether the eventual show of force would match the president’s apocalyptic rhetoric.

title: The Hardest Part of Setting a Guinness World Record? Getting People to Show Up.
summary: When it comes to mass-participation events, would-be record setters are finding it harder than ever to draw a crowd. But it’s still fun to try.

title: Israel Hasn’t Prosecuted a Single Suspect for the Oct. 7 Attack
summary: Israel has extensively documented the 2023 Hamas-led assault and is believed to be holding at least 200 Palestinians suspected of involvement. Not one has been charged or put on trial.

title: What It Takes to Find Food in Gaza
summary: Starvation has spread in Gaza, as the prices of basic goods have skyrocketed and getting aid is difficult and often deadly. Ashley Wu, a graphics reporter for The New York Times, explains the dire choices that many Gazans face, as Israel faces growing condemnation over the crisis.

title: Gaza Plan Stokes Tension Between Israel’s Military Chief and Government
summary: Lt. Gen. Eyal Zamir has pushed back against a proposal to control Gaza City, according to officials. One hard-right member of the government suggested he could be dismissed.

title: Meat Is Back at Eleven Madison Park, After 4 Vegan Years
summary: The Manhattan restaurant drew global praise and skepticism with its climate-minded, all-plant menu. Now its chef wants to be more welcoming — and popular.

title: How a U.S. Senate Race Is Shaping the Fight Over Redistricting in Texas
summary: Senator John Cornyn and Attorney General Ken Paxton are vying to be the tougher candidate on Democratic lawmakers who left Texas, as potential Democratic rivals seek their own spotlight.

title: Cuomo’s Attack on Mamdani’s Apartment Struck a New York Nerve
summary: The attacks in the New York City mayor’s race may have veered into the personal, but they also reflected a larger debate on who should benefit from government regulation of housing costs.

title: Ex-Governor Switches Back to Eric Adams in NYC Mayor’s Race
summary: Former Gov. David Paterson, who had endorsed his successor, Andrew Cuomo, in the Democratic primary, said he believed Mr. Adams “would run the city the best.”

title: U.K. Secretly Spent $3.2 Million to Stop Journalists From Reporting on Data Breach
summary: After British authorities accidentally exposed information about 19,000 Afghans, the government sought a legal order preventing disclosure of the breach.

title: Homeless and Burning in America’s Hottest City
summary: As the summer heat becomes increasingly extreme in Phoenix, people who can’t escape the sun are suffering third-degree burns, heatstroke and dehydration.

title: Juneau Floods As Mendenhall Glacier Melts
summary: An overflowing glacial lake caused a surge in the Mendenhall River on Wednesday, prompting flood alerts and evacuations in Juneau.

title: At Least 3 Are Killed in Tennessee Flooding
summary: Rescue crews pulled people out of submerged cars and homes overnight as floods swept the southeastern part of the state.

title: Beyoncé Wins First Emmy for N.F.L. Halftime Show
summary: The pop superstar received a costume design award for her Netflix football halftime performance tied to her “Cowboy Carter” album.

title: The Strange Beauty of New York’s Bodega Ramps
summary: These humble, concrete blobs, designed to ease entry into delis and other stores, can resemble glaciers, pancakes or clamshells and affirm the civic compact.

title: Trump Wants to Take Over the Fortune 500. What Can Go Wrong?
summary: Our commander in chief has decided to also command the Fortune 500.

title: In ‘And Just Like That …’ a Craven Era Took Its Revenge on Youth and Hope and Fun
summary: Every generation gets the “Sex and the City” version it deserves.

title: Hard Truths
summary: We look at how the Trump administration deals with unfavorable data.

title: New Video Shows Uvalde School Chief Trying to Negotiate With Gunman
summary: The video, part of a trove of materials that authorities had refused to release, shows the minutes in which a commander tried to talk to a gunman barricaded in a room with dozens of children.

title: New York City Companies All but Stopped Hiring in First Half of the Year
summary: Fewer than 1,000 private-sector jobs were added, the slowest growth in the labor market outside a recession and the pandemic since 2003.

title: Why Cristiano Ronaldo’s Engagement Raised Eyebrows in Saudi Arabia
summary: The soccer star has been living in the country with Georgina Rodríguez, the mother of his children, testing the boundaries of social change in the conservative Islamic kingdom.
